Award.AwardTitle: Problems in arithmetic groups and multiple Dirichlet series.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on problems in arithmetic groups and multiple Dirichlet series, problems that are intimately related to automorphic forms. One part addresses topics related to cohomology of arithmetic groups and allied areas, such as the geometry of locally symmetric spaces and the conjectures linking cohomology to arithmetic geometry and Galois representations. The second part studies multiple Dirichlet series attached to Weyl groups, affine Weyl groups, and principal homogeneous vector spaces, and their connections to combinatorics, representation theory, automorphic forms, and mathematical physics. As writing projects, the principal investigator will continue to work with F. Hirzebruch and D. Zagier on updating their book "The Atiyah-Singer theorem and elementary number theory." He will also work with W. Stein to prepare a revised version of "Modular forms, a computational approach."

This proposal deals with the interactions between number theory and representation theory. Number theory is the study of the properties of the whole numbers, and is the oldest branch of mathematics. Representation theory is the systematic study of symmetry, through the development of simple mathematical objects that encode the fundamental irreducible pieces of symmetry. A principal aim of the proposal is to explore relationships between these two subjects in the spirit of the "Langlands philosophy," which predicts deep connections between number theory and representation theory. Today the questions and phenomena addressed by these subjects serve as driving forces in much of contemporary mathematics research. Moreover, the subjects have contributed many applications in such diverse areas as codes and data transmission, chemistry, physics, and theoretical computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of study of this NSF funded project was number theory.
Number theory is one of the oldest subjects in mathematics, and today
has applications in other fields of mathematics and in theoretical
physics, and even in contemporary society through its connection to
cryptography and secure communication.  Typical questions addressed by
number theory include "How can one efficiently factor whole numbers
into primes?", and "How often is a random selected whole number
prime?"  The tools used in modern number theory include everything
from the geometry of exotic spaces to functions built from arithmetic
data, and also refined notions of symmetry that arise when one studies
deeper structures in arithmetic.
 
This project focused on two distinct research areas in
contemporary number theory: (1) the computational investigation of the
cohomology of arithmetic groups, and (2) investigation of multiple
Dirichlet series.  An additional component (3) addressed preparing an
updated version of a classic research monograph.

In area (1), the principal investigator (PI) developed algorithms and
computer code to perform large scale computations that explored
connections between geometry and number theory.  More precisely,
recent work of Scholze confirms that the topology of certain geometric
spaces encodes interesting and otherwise inaccessible objects in
number theory, namely Galois representations; these are the objects
that reveal the deeper symmetries in arithmetic alluded to above.  He
and his collaborators used computer experiments to detect these
objects and to accumulate data about them for use by other
researchers.  This data was then used to provide evidence for further
connections between topology and number theory, and in particular
helped to formulate conjectures about torsion classes in the
cohomology of arithmetic groups.  The data has been disseminated to
the general public through the L-functions and modular forms database
(lmfdb.org).

In area (2), the PI and his collaborators studied the structure of
certain functions built from arithmetic data called multiple Dirichlet
series.  These functions have become increasingly important in number
theory, since they have shown to have interesting relationships to
representation theory and mathematical physics.  The PI and his
collaborators have developed many of these connections.

In area (3), the PI has been engaged in a long term writing project
with Don Zagier to prepare an updated version of "The Atiyah-Singer
Index Theorem and Elementary Number Theory."  This book was originally
written by Hirzebruch and Zagier in the 70's and discussed further
connections between topology and number theory.  Significant progress
was made on the writing of this book during the course of the project,
including incorporating exposition of results of the PI from other
NSF-funded projects.

This NSF project has had significant broader impacts.  The tools, data, and
algorithms developed by the PI have been used by other researchers.
The products of the grant have appeared in research journals and have
been presented at meetings and in research seminars.  The PI also used
material in the project to supervise junior faculty research
(postdocs) and the research of graduate students.  He co-organized
international meetings in the US, Canada, and Germany that explored
topics in the proposal and had significant impact on the research of
others.  He also mentored mathematics research of talented high-school
students through participation in the PROMYS program.
